boardgame.name: Primus
boardgame.description:
Primus is deducted from the game Neutron from Robert A. Kraus (I). But while Neutron is for 2 players and heavily unbalanced, Primus is for 2-4 players and by using 4 instead of only 1 neutron it is a really great enhancement to Neutron.

The whole board is 8x8 spaces, but the outer rows and columns serve as home bases for the players only. The game itself is played on the 6x6 inner part of the board.

The 4 neutrons are placed in the middle of the board. Object of the game is to get the most points by moving these neutrons to the home bases. The neutrons are worth 3, 6, 8 and 10 points, depending on the order, when they have been captured. That means, the first captured neutron gives 3 points, the second 6 and so on.

After all, Primus is much better balanced than Neutron and the clever point values forces the players to think at more than just at capturing every reachable neutron.

boardgame.name: Camorra
boardgame.description:
This game is played on a simplified map of Naples. The board shows 4 administration offices, about 100 houses of 4 different categories and clearly marked streets and places.

Each player chooses a headquarter, where his actions begin. He will hire some tokens, send them out to claim a street, a place or occupy a house. Houses are the only possibility to earn money, but money is much needed, because every location must be defended (with money) against hostile take-overs.

Hiring new tokens is always possible, but the more money you collect, the more they cost. Streets and places are needed to accelerate the movement of the tokens and can only be used by their owners.

Winner of the game is the player who occupies 3 administration offices first – or 4, if a longer game is desired.

boardgame.name: UNO: Cars
boardgame.description:
The usual Uno rules - Players race to empty their hands and catch opposing players with cards left in theirs, which score points. In turns, players attempt to play a card by matching its color or number to the topmost card on the discard pile. If unable to play, players draw cards from the draw pile until they are able to place a card. Wild and special cards spice things up a bit. Additionally, when playing their penultimate card from their hand, players must shout 'UNO' or face a forfeit of drawing two further cards.

WHAT MAKES THIS DIFFERENT FROM TRADITIONAL UNO: Victory Lap Card. When played, each player puts their hand face down on the table and passes it to the next player. Only the player of the victory lap card gets to look at the hand in front of them, which they choose to either keep or pass. If they keep passing, the hands keep getting passed around, until the Victory Lap player selects a hand to keep. Play then continues with all players adopting the new decks they now have in front of them.

boardgame.name: Schere, Stein, Papier
boardgame.description:
Each of the 3 players has 10 double sided playing pieces:

- 3 x Rock/Scissors
- 3 x Scissors/Paper
- 3 x Paper/Rock
- 1 king (showing Rock, Scissors or Paper on both sides)

The game is played on a triangular board of 45 hexes. Each corner section of the board is reserved as staring position for the 3 players, but the arrangement of the pieces can be freely chosen.

Object of the game is to capture the opposing kings. The player with a king is the winner.

Each turn, a player can move 1 stone and flip over 1 stone. Captures are done by comparing the upper(valid) side of a stone using the well known Rock-Scissors-Paper mechanism.

boardgame.name: Obstsalat
boardgame.description:
The game "Obstsalat" (=fruit salad) was included in Spielbox 1/87 as part of the "Spiel zum Herausnehmen/Game to Remove" series.
The board is divided into 4 parts. Each part is the playing sector of one of the 2-4 players.

Object of the game is to move all 6 playing pieces to the final space in the middle of the board. The first player reaching this, is the winner.

Movement is done by throwing 2 dice, one normal die and one colour die. The normal die determines the number of spaces a playing piece can move, the color die enables the use of shortcuts of the appropriate color, though throwing black lets the piece move backwards.

Jumping over pieces is not allowed and landing on an occupied space lets the piece go back to the start.

boardgame.name: Break Away
Breakaway
boardgame.description:
Break Away was originally published in the July 1983 issue of Games magazine, and was reprinted in Spielbox 4/87 as part of the "Spiel zum Herausnehmen/Game to Remove" series.

The board has 5x6 spaces and each player has 7 playing pieces. At the start of the game, all playing pieces are placed on the board, but not on fixed locations. In fact, one player places the pieces on the board and the other player chooses the color he wants to play with.

Object of the game is to "break away" all your playing pieces: as soon as a player manages to have all his 7 pieces isolated, that is with no own neighbors on all adjacent spaces, he is the winner.

The number of spaces a piece must move is ruled in an unusual way, too: 1, 2, or 3 spaces, alternating with every move of each player (resulting in 1-3-2-1-3-2-1-3-2... for a single player).

boardgame.name: Spontan, Woran denkst 'n Du ?
boardgame.description:
This is a game for ages 14 and up. The box contains a board, 8 pawns, cards and an hour-glass.

The cards contain numbers (1 to 6) and words.

On your turn you have to call a number, take a card from the stack and read the word next to the number you have called. You write down the first word that comes into your mind. The other players have now to guess one by one what word you have written down.

If someone guesses the right word you can both move your pawn 2 fields on the board. If no one was able to guess the right word, everybody can guess as long as the hour-glass keeps running (45 sec). If someone is able to guess the right word now, you can both move your pawn one field on the board.

The first player to reach the destination field on the board is the winner of the game.

boardgame.name: Das Kapital
boardgame.description:
The game "Das Kapital" was included in Spielbox 4/82 as part of the "Spiel zum Herausnehmen/Game to Remove" series.

It is played on a triangular board with 81 hex spaces. It is a variation of a chess game for 3 players. And as in chess, the object of the game is the capture of the opposing king(s).

Each player has 9 playing pieces:

- 1 Kapital (similar to the king in chess)
- 1 Intelligenz (similar to the knight)
- 1 Kirche (similar to the rook)
- 1 Militär (similar to the bishop)
- 1 Politiker (similar to the queen)
- 4 Arbeiter (similar to the pawn)

The total number of playing pieces is exactly 1/3 (27) of the board size of 81. And since 54 spaces are empty at the beginning, a slower development of the game is achieved.

Several additions are made to the normal rules, like enabling the capture of own pieces (which allows an additional move) or making a putsch against the own pieces. It's not explicitly mentioned, but I guess, these additions can be left away to play the game.

boardgame.description:
In Anagramme, two players (or teams) compete to find anagrams of French words as quickly as possible.

Each side of a card shows five words, and the words on the opposite side are their anagrams. Schatzsuche
Skatteøen
Skatteøya
Skattkammarön
boardgame.description:
This is a game for ages 5 and up. The box contains a board, 4 wooden pawns, 1 die, 7 castle cards and 27 equipment cards.

The board shows a tract around a robbers castle. The castle has 7 entrances. The castle cards are placed face down on these entrances. The castle cards are showing robbers, vermin or the treasure.

There are 3 kinds of equipment cards : hats, keys and boats. The cards of the same kind have a similar look. The cards are placed next to the board, one stack per kind.

Each player gets a pawn and tries to get the treasure out of the castle.

On your turn you roll the die and move your pawn accordingly. An action takes place when your pawn ends on a special field.
When your pawn lands on a boat field, you get a boat card. Landing on a hat field gives you a hat card and landing on a key field gives you a key card.
When your pawn ends on a sleeping robber, you can roll a second time. A horse helps you move faster, if your pawn lands on a horse field you can move to a field of your choice.
If you land on a fallen tree field, you have to skip one turn and landing on the bridge will cause you to lose all your equipment cards.

If your pawn arrives on an already occupied field, you can take one equipment card of the player whose pawn was already on that field.

Your pawn can go to the castle if he lands on a pier. Therefor you have to hand in one of each of the three kinds of equipment cards. On your next turn your pawn can move on one of the 7 castle cards and turn it face up. If that castle card shows a spider, a ghost or a bat , you can turn the card face down again and move 1 field further. If the castle card shows a robber you have to start all over again.

The game ends as soon as a player has found the treasure card.

boardgame.name: Malvinas
boardgame.description:
The Falklands ("Malvinas" in Spanish) are a small group of islands in the South Atlantic that have caused a diplomatic conflict between Argentina and the UK since 1833.

On the 2nd April 1982 Argentinian forces invaded the islands, which started the Falklands' War. The British reaction was immediate and on the 5th April the first forces sailed to the Falklands. The Argentinians surrendered on the 14th June.

The Falklands' War was the largest air and sea operation since WWII and highlighted the importance in modern warfare of logistics, missiles (air-air, ship-air), the air forces, professional troops, etc.

boardgame.name: 6x5
boardgame.description:
6x5 is an abstract version of Xochintlan. Instead of using an Aztec background and square tiles, 6x5 sticks to basic colors and hexagon shaped tiles. This new version has a slightly different set of rules and also provides more variants.

Each player gets a Goal Card showing a pattern of 5 hexagons (among the 32 provided in the game). Everyone shares the very same 25 hexagons to build their pattern: 8 blue, 8 red, 8 yellow and 1 black. You try to be the first one to realize your pattern. To win, you must include in your pattern the black hexagon, and the 4 others must be of the same color (either all blue, all red or all yellow).

Whenever you get closer to your own goal, you might actually be helping your opponent as well. You cannot just focus on your own pattern, you must also try to decipher your opponent's and prevent it from being realized.

This game is freely accessible on the author's website.

boardgame.name: Battel
boardgame.description:
An abstract dice game from the 1970's. The board is composed of three squares, the inner square having 9 spaces with the numbers 1, 2 or 3. The players throw two dice and place their chips according to the result. With a 6 a chip can be placed on one of the starting positions. From there it can be moved with the result of the 2nd dice. If a player lands on an occupied space, he can throw out the other chip. Only on the inner 9 spaces on the board, players can score in the end.
After all 9 inner spaces have been occupied, the game ends and the players count points by multiplying the number of chips with the according number it stands on.

boardgame.name: ¿Resiste Stalingrado?
boardgame.description:
Among the great battles in the Eastern Front during WWII, undoubtedly Stalingrad was the most touching and one of the most decisive for the outcome of the war.

The Soviet plan to hunt and destroy, unit by unit, the 6th German Army lead by Von Paulus was a masterpiece in its design and execution by Zukov. During two and a half months, 22 German divisions were sieged in the city, defending themselves from the Red Army onslaught, street by street and house by house. All the German attempts were
in vain.

Attacks and counterattacks were continuous and the casualties for both sides were very high. Finally, on the 31st January 1943 Von Paulus surrenders: the powerful 6th Army did no longer exist and from then on, the war in the East Front turned around.

boardgame.name: Hermagor
boardgame.description:
In a distant land, many and many years ago, rose a big and wealthy city: its name, now forgotten by most, was Hermagor. Commerce was the source of its richness, because from all its territory countrymen, artisans and also adventurers brought to the city every kind of merchandise: weapons, ancient books, precious relics, and rare dragon eggs. In this city, you can buy and exchange everything. This made Hermagor famous and merchants came from afar to buy and sell all kinds of goods at the market. Some even undertook perilous adventures to acquire especially rare items. They criss-crossed this wealthy region, creating new paths and roads, adding markets to towns, but always with the aim to become the richest!

Set in the imaginary land of Hermagor, each player takes on the role of a merchant striving to be the wealthiest trader. While playing, they aim to acquire goods in the marketplace and then sell those goods profitably in the towns and villages across land of Hermagor. Players first gain access to goods tiles in the marketplace by placing their agents in proximity to the tiles they want. Then the players move one agent across the map of Hermagor, visiting and selling goods in the towns requesting goods that match the tiles the player acquired in the marketplace.

Hermagor is played in five rounds with two phases in each round. Each round begins with the marketplace phase. Players pay to place their four agents in the market trying to control the goods tiles they will use in the second phase of the round. Control of a tile goes to the player who has the most agents next to the tile. Ties are broken by the priority of the adjacent locations. Agents adjacent to the sides of a tile take priority over agents adjacent to the corner of tiles. An agent placed on a tile has the highest priority. After all agents have been placed and tiles claimed by the players, the marketplace agents also generate income. Agents in the same row or column generate income at the rate of 1 for 1 agent, 3 for 2 agents, 6 for 3 agents, and 10 for 4 agents. The price for placing agents depends on the location. Locations that apply control to more tiles cost more.

Each round concludes with selling phase. Players take turns moving one agent across the map of Hermagor, paying a price for each road segment they use so that they can sell goods in a town or village. Importantly, each player may only sell in any town or village once during the game. Players mark each town or village where they have sold goods with a house. Players receive a small monetary reward when other players sell in a town or village that the player has already sold in. Selling goods in all the towns or villages surrounding a region of the map defined by a set of roads potentially gives the player the right to a production facility in that region, supplying additional income immediately and at the end of the game.

Hermagor ends when the last player finishes his turn of the selling phase of the fifth round. End game bonus money is awarded for production facilities, most sales along the major road, and for the smallest of each players sales locations in each of the three Hermagor regions defined by its rivers.

The player with the most money at the end of the game wins.

boardgame.name: Soap Opera Challenge: General Hospital
boardgame.description:
[From back of card deck:]

"Challenge yourself and your friends to remember great moments from General Hospital including the stormy marriage of Alan and Monica and the adventures of Anna, Duke and Scorpio."

This is a trivia game consisting of 54 cards and a "drama die". There are 6 categories of trivia questions:

1. Love Affairs and Friendships

2. The Family Tree

3. Characters and Circumstance

4. Disappearing Acts

5. It's a Crime

6. Challenge Plus (extra-difficult questions)

Each face of the die has a logo corresponding to one of the 6 categories. A player rolls a die and has the top card of the deck read to them, based on the category rolled. If the question is answered correctly, the person keeps the card and rolls again. If incorrect, the card goes on the bottom of the deck, and it's the next players turn.

The game is over when the draw deck is empty. The person with the most cards wins.

Note that due to the recycling of the cards, this can be a very lengthy game if the players are not experts on General Hospital of the mid 1980s.

There are also rules for solo play (go through the deck once, rolling the die for each one -- if you get 27 or more correct, you win.

A player rolls a die and has the top card of the deck read to them, based on the number rolled. If the question is answered correctly, the person keeps the card and rolls again. If incorrect, the card goes on the bottom of the deck, and it's the next players turn.

The game is over when the draw deck is empty. The person with the most cards wins.

Note that due to the recycling of the cards, this can be a very lengthy game if the players are not experts on General Hospital of the 1980s.

There are also rules for solo play (go through the deck once, rolling the die for each one -- if you get 27 or more correct, you win).

Also, as mentioned on the back of the card deck, included as a bonus are 9 recipes inspired by the characters of General Hospital.

boardgame.name: Grand Total
boardgame.description:
Grand Total is "Mathematical Equation Scrabble." Players place number and symbol tiles in a line to form an equation, scoring points for the number they use.

The board is large (18" square), colorful, and well-designed. It is ruled off in 1" squares, with numbers from 0 to 9 printed in about 10% of the squares. The tiles are cardboard counters of decent thickness - the numbers are red and the symbols (+, -, and =) yellow.

Players mix up the tiles, then draw seven numbers and three signs. In turn, each player places tiles on the board to make a "legal" equation, using at least one tile already on the board, crossword-style. Typical Scrabble rules are used regarding challenges and redraws. Player score the sum of the numbers they used, disregarding the results of the equation they formed. If a tile is placed on a space bearing the same number, it's double score.

A surprising rule is that a player may remove the equal sign from an equation on the board and replace it with a plus or minus if they can form a new equation that way. The removed "=" is reused further down the new equation.

Game meant for 2nd/3rd Grade and up.

boardgame.name: Hoplon 3
boardgame.description:
Hoplon 3 is the third edition of a fast play set of ancient and medieval miniatures rules using an amended version of the DBx basing system. This allows players with DBx-based armies to play Hoplon with only minimum changes necessary.
Although designed for 15mm miniatures, the system also supports 25/28mm play. Hoplon has been extensively play-tested in clubs and by members of a dedicated Yahoo group, and this testing has led to a number of revisions which have been incorporated into the third edition.

The philosophy behind Hoplon is to provide an easy-to-learn but deep system emphasizing the relative capabilities of different troop types and morale classes, the difficulties of effective command and control and -most of all - the close matching of historical tactics and performance.

In Hoplon, armies are separated into commands, and commands are separated into units. Troops are activated and controlled by means of command points. While single elements can function individually, they do so at a cost when detached from their parent formations, losing their unit's stamina, cohesion bonus, and ability to maneuver in groups. This in turn forces players to deal with the tactical control problems inherent in commanding large bodies of ancient and medieval troops. Sequence of play is by interleaved-Command (both players moving on the same round by order of initiative of their commands) rather than alternating on every round, which makes tactical decision-making all the more interesting.

While it uses a points system and army lists loosely based on the DBM model, Hoplon has taken a fresh approach to game-play which provides a realistic and historically satisfying simulation of ancient and medieval warfare. As a result, most historical battles require little or no tweaking to re-fight making this set a real tool for simulating actual battles.

boardgame.name: Go-nin-Kan
Kan
Kankei
ゴニンカン
boardgame.description:
A Japanese Traditional Trick/Picture-cards Taking Game by ad hoc-team


Here is Japan. The winter of the north country Tsugaru is in the deep snow. But even so there, flowers of the trick-taking game had quietly and gallantly flourished!

Kan is the short form of the Kankei(relationship). At first, Kankei team and Non-Kankei teams are determined by dealt cards and the fight against each other for the 16 picture cards(Each A, K, Q and J). Friends in earlier rounds could be opponents for the next deal!

A deal consists of ten tricks. Trumps are determined each deal. For each individual case, each player should try to guess what in other players hands and then try to help each other according to game-rules using the cards in one's hand.

If Kankei team wins, they will play same team up to 3 deals. At 2nd and/or 3rd deal of same Kankei team, they can decide trump suit from definite information.

At Go-nin-Kan (or 5 hands Kan), Kankei team consist of two players against Non-Kankei team with three. If a player plays as a dealer, the game becomes easier and smooth. (At official tournament, always six players play.)

You can play less than five players with Variant rules.

For four hands, Damari-Kan (quiet Kan, two against two).
For three hands, Ganbari-Kan (bearing Kan, one against two).


Japon Brand version


The special deck of the Go-nin-Kan from JAPON BRAND featured Japanese four seasons as suits (Spring: Night cherry blossom. Summer: Beech leaf. Autumn: Apple fruit. Winter: Snow crystal). As picture cards, the Japanese summer celebrations Neputa(sleeping-purging) and Mushi-Okuri(worm-purging) are illustrated. In addition, this set includes marker cards for displaying examples of playing situation.

We wish for you to experience Japanese and/or Tsugaru soul!

boardgame.description:
Designed by Steve Alexander and published by Millennium Games, AIR ATTACK! is a game “where you are the squadron commander of a tactical fighter squadron. Your mission - to bomb your opponent’s military targets while protecting your own. Other forces include surface-to-air missiles and an electronic warfare bomber at your disposal.”
This game contains rules for Basic Game and Advanced Version.

AIR ATTACK! comes in a 8.25"x11.5"x1" game box with one 4-color 16"x21.5" map sheet; one counter sheet with 40 single sided die cut cardboard counters; a 16 page rulebook; and two six-sided dice.

This game can be played by two to four players, has moderate solitaire capability, low complexity, and playing time for a game is “coffee break” short for the Basic Game, but Advanced game will run longer.

This is a very simple game, with fairly nice production quality. It has some chrome elements that may contribute to repeat plays. It would serve as a fairly quick and easy introduction to air wargaming for kids and adults new to wargaming.

boardgame.name: Jacob und seine Freunde
boardgame.description:
Jacob, a comic figure drawn by Sven Hartmann, is a cat. He has 4 animal friends, Pump, Flap, Pingi and Patsch - all are seen here.

The game is played on a 9x8 board. 20 tiles show 4 x Jacob and his 4 friends. The tiles are randomly placed on the board face down. Each player puts the playing piece of his neighbor on an empty space of the board and the game can begin.

Object of the game is to collect 4 tiles with each friend of Jacob. The player who achieves this first, is the winner of the game.

Movements of the playing pieces are handled in a very unusual way: each row of the board shows a number, which indicates the distance that a pieces must move (in any direction). If a piece lands on a tile, the player looks at it secretly and keeps it, if he does not have it already. If he finds a piece already in his collection, he puts it back on a empty space of his choice. This can not only confuse the player's memory, it can also be made in a more strategical way, because the movements of the playing pieces are defined by the already mentioned number of the rows.

boardgame.name: Battlefield Evolution: Ultra-Modern Tabletop Combat
boardgame.description:
From Mongoose Publishing:

Welcome to the battlefield of the near future!

Battlefield Evolution is a fast-paced and easy to learn miniatures game, with enough tactical depth to keep you hooked for years. You will command small forces based on real world armies of the near future, and attempt to overwhelm your opponents with tactical skill and a healthy dose of luck!

Based on supposition and projection of real world armies in the near future, this game features new technologies that are just around the corner – you will be among the first to experience how such weapons and equipment can affect the modern battlefield from the point of view of a soldier. There are several different armies to collect, each with a wide range of units and tactical abilities

Battlefield Evolution features simple, yet tactically challenging rules and expert-level pre-painted models in every box set!

boardgame.name: Grand Slam Tennisspel
boardgame.description:
A tennis game where the outcome of each shot is determined by rolling a die. Each ball is a series of rolls of the five different dice. There is one die for serves, one for second serve, one for baseline play, one for short balls and one for high balls.

There are no choices to be made. The dice are rolled back and forth between the two players until someone wins the ball. With this tool for determine balls, matches can be played according to normal tennis rules. There are no rules for which of the players of one side is rolling dice when, when playing doubles.

From package (rough translation from Swedish): "With Grand Slam Tennisspel you can play tennis wherever you are. You can play single or double. Always exciting."

boardgame.name: Erb-Schleicher AG
Erbschleicher AG
boardgame.description:
The players are relatives of aunt Luzie, who is soon going to die. Aim of the game is to inherit some of aunt Luzie's wealth.
To get to her money the players have a set of legacy-hunter-cards, from which 5 cards are drawn in the beginning. They are gifts for aunt Luzie. The inheritance cards are shuffled and placed in the middle of the board.
Every turn the players give aunt Luzie gifts like journeys or parties in form of the legacy-hunter-cards, which have a certain value from 1-6. Every player is allowed to give one card. In the 2nd phase another card can be placed to increase chances or to pick another category. After all players have placed cards aunt Luzie is moved around (dice) and according where she lands the player with the highest card(s) in that category inherits something.
The player with the most valuable inheritance cards in the end wins.

boardgame.name: Encounter at Hanover
boardgame.description:
Encounter at Hanover is a promotional game for the town of Hanover, Pennsylvania, sponsored by the Hanover General Hospital Auxiliary.

Hanover is mostly famous for being the site of an American Civil War battle in the Gettysburg campaign. While the name of the game (the same as a book on the battle) and the box cover (which shows ACW soldiers) suggest a wargame of some kind, the game is in fact similar to Monopoly.

As in Monopoly players move around the board buying properties and improving them. Here the properties are local Hanover business and the improvements are franchises instead of houses . The rules are similar to Monopoly's with some exceptions, the main one being that ownership of a group is not required for development, but owning three properties in a row triples rent on them.

boardgame.name: Operation Tannhäuser
Tannhäuser
boardgame.description:
In 1949, this incessant war has been raging for 35 years and finally a secret archaeological dig has delivered to the Obscura Korps a long sought ancient relic. This artifact is thought to guard an ancient parcel of knowledge. The exact emplacement of one of the four dark cardinal corners of reality is on the verge of being revealed.

A portal leading to hell, this un-sanctified zone is found buried within the secular crypt of a fortress situated in the heart of central Europe. The Reich's 13th Occult Division is there now. They are about to call upon the Cohorts of Chaos to help them force the world into eternal servitude.

Parachuted behind enemy lines, a fistful of men and women are all the Union has left to thwart this peculiar menace. The Unions finest trained commandos armed with technology still in its experimental stages, the glory bound 42nd Alter-Marine Special Forces must now face the most terrible danger to face humanity in recorded history.

Tannhäuser goes beyond the standard package of set of characters, proposing a vast array of customization, allowing players to develop a unique tactic and style of play for their hero. 10 charismatic personalties await them to be groomed for battle, using over 70 magnificently illustrated types of tokens that faithfully depict various weapons, medals, ranks, powers and equipment.

Rules revised by:

Tannhäuser Revised Edition Rulebook

boardgame.name: Vabanque
boardgame.description:
This is a game for ages 12 and up. the box contains a board, 12 small pawns, 12 large pawns, 3 turntables and 24 cards.

The board shows 6 colored rows, with each 18 fields. The rows are placed parallel to one another on the board. Two start and two destination fields are located on the ends of each row.

The turntables have each a different amount of fields. The first one only shows values from 1 to 3. The second one shows the values 3, 5, 7, 9 and several times 0. The third one can be used to try to double the number of fields your pawns can move.

There are 3 categories of cards : joker, super joker and stop cards.

For starters, each player gets 4 pawns (2 small and 2 large)of one color and 4 cards (2 joker, 1 super joker and 1 stop card). The pawns are placed on their start fields.

On your turn you can turn one of the two turntables with numbers. You can move one of your pawns accordingly. If you want to, you can turn the third turntable and try to double the distance your pawn can move.

A field can never contain more than one pawn. You can leap over your pawns.

If there are pawns on the fields parallel to the one where a large pawn is landing, the pawns on the parallel fields have to restart. Little pawns can never cause a restart to other pawns.

You can influence the course of the game by using the cards. Playing a joker befor you turn one of the turntables will double your result. The superjoker can be played after you have turned one of the turntables to double the result. The stop card can be used to stop one of the other players during his turn, but only when that player didn't play a joker or superjoker.

The game ends as soon as one of players has placed his 4 pawns on his destination fields.

boardgame.name: Dallas
boardgame.description:
This is a game for ages 10 and up. The theme is based on the TV show with the same name.

The aim of the game is to earn as much money as possible. You can achieve that by buying and selling cattle, oil sources or farmland. Other sources of income are the rents for ranches. These rents are higher for more expensive ranches and are getting even higher if the owner owns several ranches.

If you succeed in buying and selling often, you will gain money more easily.

The game is played on a board comparable with a Monopoly board. The game mechanics are the same as those used for playing Monopoly.

boardgame.name: Armageddon
boardgame.description:
The game "Armageddon" was included in Spielbox 3/83 as part of the "Spiel zum Herausnehmen/Game to Remove" series. The introduction refers to Armageddon: Das strategische Fantasyspiel, because the Spielbox game plays in the same fantasy world, "Magira".

Armageddon has rules for a simplified game as well as for an advanced game. Both versions are played on a 17×20 hex board showing Magira with 1 fortification in the middle and 2 on the sides.

The easier version is played with 12 axe men, 12 pikemen and 12 swordsmen only. Object of the game is to capture the fortress in the middle of the board. All types of warriors have the same movement factor. Combats are decided by the throw of 1 die, but several bonus point are added to the throw. One of them is a kind of Rock-Scissors-Paper effect, because an axeman fighting a pikeman, a pikeman against a swordsman and a swordsman against an axeman gets 1 bonus point.

The advanced version adds several new units (archers, horsemen, veterans, horses), enables ranged attacks, combat support possibilities and faster movements. The victory condition stays the same.

There is also a variation, where a siege of a fortress is simulated.

boardgame.name: Quadriga
boardgame.description:
The game "Quadriga" was included in Spielbox 4/81 and is the first game of the "Spiel zum Herausnehmen/Game to Remove" series.

It depicts the chariot races in ancient Rome. Up to 8 teams race around the track twice to determine victory.

Several obstacles and narrow curves make it difficult to drive the chariots. Therefore, accidents are likely to occur and since completely destroyed chariots stay on the track where eliminated, the difficulties even rise further.

Included to the game is an additional scenario. It is based on the novel "Sagare" from Tanith Lee and it includes many aspects from that novel: earth, air, water and fire obstacles as well as furious archers.

boardgame.name: Napoleon
boardgame.description:
The game "Napoleon" was included in Spielbox 6/86 as part of the "Spiel zum Herausnehmen/Game to Remove" series.

Thought as an introduction to Cosim games, this game has simplified wargame rules. Anyway, the Allied and French forces enter play according to a detailed time plan.

The hex board is somehow exchangeable for Napoleonic battles, because no village names are marked on it and the victory conditions are not different for the 2 players (like in most Napoleonic games).

The game ends after 20 rounds and the object of the game is to score the most points, which are won by capturing opposing forces or occupying certain map points at the end of the game.

boardgame.name: Kan Zen
boardgame.description:
From the bottom of the box:

Kan Zen: the perfect word game

A GAME AND A WORLD:

KAN ZEN (tm) is more than a game. It is a world. In that world there is a place for everyone, and fun for everyone. There is also a place for all of the words on earth - those in your own language, those in foreign languages, ordinary words, and words that are the names of persons or places - if the letters of an alphabet can be used to spell them.

The game can be as easy, or as difficult, as the players choose to make it - among yourselves you agree on the kind of words that are to be used. The playing time can be readily adjusted to suit your convenience.

Above all, KAN ZEN is a world for those who let their imagination soar, discovering how much enjoyment they can have with a game that permits almost infinite variation.

KAN ZEN AT A GLANCE:

The board is a circular track, on which a step is taken for each letter of a word played. Letters drawn at random at the beginning of each move must be included in the words that you use. UP-TURNS, where the TALLY (letter count) is added to your score, alternate with DOWN-TURNS, where the TALLY is subtracted, unless evasive action is taken. The "perfect" words are those whose TALLIES enable you to move to sectors of the circle where the best advantage can be taken on multiple scoring opportunities on UP-TURNS or where losses can be avoided or minimized on DOWN-TURNS. The winner is the player with the highest net accumulative TALLY at the end of the game.

HOW MANY CAN PLAY?

Two, three or four sides can play the highly competitive versions of the The Perfect Word Game - as individuals, partners or teams.

The game can also be played "solo". Those who love words, or who find pleasure in drawing on a well-stocked memory of names of persons and places, may well consider KAN ZEN the best solitaire game in the world.

boardgame.description:
This is a board game designed to teach non-American children the rules of the road and roadsigns. It utilizes international road signs and traffic signals that change. Age range 8-99.

The idea is you visit various addresses drawn from cards but must get there by rolling the dice and obeying all traffic laws and signals as you maneuver your car through the city. Other players also have their goals. It was fun to play as a kid. Probably could be easily adopted to US roadsigns.

It would also be useful for adults from North America traveling to other locations, who intend to rent/drive a car there, as a quick way to learn/refresh knowledge on the road signs used in most parts of the world.

boardgame.name: Campionato del mondo
Championnat du monde
Världsmästare
Verdensmester
Weltmeisterschaft
World Cup
Worldcup
boardgame.description:
World Cup is a soccer game which is played in 2 phases, the arrangement of the teams phase and the soccer match phase.

There are 32 soccer player cards in 4 colors, as well as 12 Superstar cards and 12 Fan cards included. Each player is dealt 4 soccer player card, 1 of each color, and some money.

During Phase-1, the players walk around a 16 space course, spend money for soccer player cards, superstars and fan cards. They also need money to make transfers with other players or to replace soccer players, which have been hurt by injuries. The strength of all teams is always kept up-to-date, because the income depends directly on it!
As soon as all soccer playing cards are sold, Phase-1 ends and players with incomplete teams pay for making up their teams again. If they don't have enough money, they get the worst available cards.

Phase-2 is the match phase (money does not help here anymore):
The matches are played on a 7x13 playing field. Each team has 3 tokens which merely serve as defenders. The ball is moved by putting cards on the table. The attacker must announce, which card(s) he wants to play and the defender can then arrange his tokens according to certain restrictions. Goals can only be realized by Superstars - but there are 12 in this game, so most matches will end with a winner. A match is finished, when one player has played all his cards.

All succeeding matches must be played with the same deck of cards, so it's clear, that Phase-1 is most important to become the final World Cup Winner.

boardgame.name: Rymdimperiet
Space Empire
boardgame.description:
Rymdimperiet (Space Empire in English) is one of the few games the Swedish publishers "Äventyrsspel" did on their own without licensing an already exciting American game. The gameplay in itself is simple and each player will play the part of a space trader shipping goods across the galaxy. The goal of the game is to generate a net of 150,000 credits and return to your home planet before any of the other players.

Players move on already existing trade routes which they later can choose to buy to make their own for a set price. Once a trade route has been bought it will earn that player revenue each time another player is forced to use that particular route, as well as create safe passage way for your own trading ship when traveling in the sense that you do not have to pay the expenses to another player and give them the edge.

Trade routes are different in length and usefulness and players will also be given the option to upgrade their ship to go in Hyperdrive, thus allowing them to move around the board to their destinations faster. The game uses a table where you look up the revenue from each trade between the starting planet and the goal for your shipment.

The element that makes the game difficult is that you cannot actively choose your trade route. It is randomly generated by dice rolls through a table to see to what area and which planet on the board you have to go to. This is also where owning and buying trade routes plays the part of a tactical element.

Re-implements:

Rail Baron

boardgame.name: Richard III: The Wars of the Roses
boardgame.description:
Richard III: The Wars of the Roses (formerly known simply as Wars of the Roses) is an epic two-player game concerning the long and bloody dynastic struggle between the houses of Lancaster and York for the throne of England. The game depicts both the vicious military campaigns and the rich political struggles that surrounded the late rule of the mad-king Henry VI, the Yorkist usurper Edward IV, the bloody rule of Richard III, and the early years of the first Tudor king, Henry VII. Also strutting across the game's stage and toward the throne is Richard of York, the patriarch of the house of Plantagenet; Richard Neville, the notorious "Kingmaker"; the iron-queen of Lancaster, Margaret of Anjou, and the would-be Lancastrian king Edward, the Prince of Wales.

The game system employed in Richard III takes off where the award-winning Hammer of the Scots left off with innovative new rules to reflect the Wars of the Roses.

boardgame.name: First to Find!
boardgame.description:
First To Find! is a two to four person geocaching themed card game that can be played in 20-30 minutes. The game captures the excitement of the international sport, Geocaching! The game features stunning, original artwork and comes in a collector's tin box!

Object: Instead of standard suits, "FTF!" features cards suited to the seasons - fall, spring, summer, and winter. Players then use a combination of Gear (e.g. bug spray), Movement (e.g. sled) and Obstacle (e.g. spider) cards in the appropriate season of play to out-trick their opponents and race to become the first person to find the treasure, a.k.a "cache."

boardgame.name: Blast-Off
boardgame.description:
This is a space race game that uses a spinner for movement and has 3 types of cards for different spaces landed upon. The goal is to complete a race around the solar system and back to earth. Entering and leaving planets requires a special roll on the spinner.

It is patented - #3985361 and the text below is from the patent.

Abstract

A game device embodying a game board having a planar playing surface having a path of movement for game pieces delineated thereon, a control spinner and directional cards positioned on the game board for controlling movement of the game pieces. The path of movement is divided into a plurality of increments or areas some of which are provided with instructional indicia. The game pieces simulate rockets and the game board, spinner, control cards and indicia relate to and are simulative of space travel.

boardgame.name: Hi Score
boardgame.description:
"Hi Score" was published in the German magazine Pöppel-Revue 5/86 as "Spiel im Heft".

The board has 6x6 spaces and both players have 18 stones, numbered from 1-18 on the front side and empty on the back side.

The game begins with an empty board. Each turn, a player places a stone on the board on the same row or column the last stone has been placed. Stones can not be moved to other spaces, but they are (must be) flipped over, if the sum of own stones in a row or column is higher than the sum of the opposing stones.

The game ends, when a player can not place a stone on the board. To determine the winner, the numbers on the not yet played stones are subtracted from the total on the stones on the board. The higher total wins.

boardgame.name: Oförberedd
boardgame.description:
Oförberedd ("unprepared") is a Swedish trivia game, but not quite like most trivia games.

The object of the game is to get through high school, get a doctorate, and finally win by becoming a professor.

When a player is still a student, his examiner (the next player) draws a card and reads a subject from that. The subject is something like "Name a city by the river ....". The examiner reads the question and fills in the blank with something of his own choosing. If the student can answer, he gets a diploma in that subject (there are four different subjects). If the student can't answer, the examiner must answer the question. If he can't, he gets a warning. Otherwise, the student gets the warning. The rest of the players are arbiters in the case of disputes as to what is the correct answer to a question.

After collecting three diplomas, the player is finished with high school and can now start working on his doctorate. To achieve that, he must get a diploma in each of the four subjects. Once he has that, he must also hold a lecture. To get the subject of his lecture, the player arranges his diplomas in a certain order and reads the sentence that this creates (if he has more than one diploma in a subject he may choose which one to use). This will result in a subject like "The bad influence / of movies / upon art / in troubled times." The student must now keep a two-minute lecture on this subject. If there are no obvious errors in his lecture, he gets his doctorate. To become a professor, the doctor must get another diploma in each subject and hold another lecture over a given subject.

Contents:
- 48 student question cards
- 16 doctor question cards
- 12 warning cards
- 64 diplomas
- 6 "finished high school" counters (student's cap)
- 6 "become a doctor" counters (doctor's hat)
- 1 "become a professor" counter (laurel)
- Rules booklet
- Booklet with explanations of questions

boardgame.name: Modular Maze Game
boardgame.description:
The primary equipment for this game consists of four plastic trays which fit together in pairs, 252 plastic walls which fit between pillars in the trays, and two marbles.

Each player takes two trays and constructs a maze in one using the walls - some walls have large holes which the marbles can pass through, some have small holes which block them. The second tray snaps onto the first to hold the walls in place. The players swap mazes and compete to be the first to get a marble through theirs.

The game also comes with clamps which hold sets of trays together to make multi-level mazes - you can make a two-level maze with a single set.

boardgame.name: The Battle of Stones River
boardgame.description:
The Battle of Stones River is a simulation of the battle of Murfreesboro in the American Civil War.

The game uses a fairly standard system reminiscent of SPI (Simulations Publications, Inc.) quads of the period. The rules do have a few points of distinction. For example, units have a stacking limit of two, and cannot attack on the same turn that a stack is created, so building up a concentrated assault takes time. The advanced rules add different movement rules for different unit types and introduce battles which can continue over more than one turn.

The game is most notable for its map, which is full-color and mounted - highly unusual for a small wargame company at the time. The map is 21.5"x22.5". Besides the map, two rules booklets, and a die, the game contains 110 counters, of which 41 are blanks.

boardgame.name: SNAFU
boardgame.description:
The board for SNAFU (which here is supposedly "Situation Normal All Filled Up" - sure) consists of 100 squares in 5 colors - red, blue, green, and yellow, all of which are assigned to the players, plus pink. Each player or team (the 4-player game is for teams) takes a color of chips, white or black.

On a turn a player spins a spinner which produces a result from 0-5 in one of the board colors or white. If the color is pink or a friendly color, the player places markers in the number of spaces shown. If an opposing color, the player may choose to place the opposing markers on the board. If white, the player takes opposing markers off the board.

The game ends when one of four possible conditions are met - one team controls the main diagonal of the board, one team controls all squares of their colors, etc. None of these conditions automatically win the game, but some add points to the team's score.

boardgame.name: Scoop: The Newspaper Game!
boardgame.description:
Scoop was one of Western's games distributed by Leisure Home Parties, which apparently was an early attempt at a home party sales approach to games. It has nothing to do with the Waddingtons/Parker Brothers game of the same name.

In this game, each player represents a newspaper trying to fill its front page, represented by a 6x8 grid. Players move around the main board buying, auctioning, and trading stories, which are thin tiles in four different sizes. The stories must be placed upright on the newspaper boards and must fit together without overlapping. Some stories have events on them, and all have fake headlines and leads.

Merchants & Marauders
Merchants and Marauders
Piraten & Kooplui
商人與掠奪者
boardgame.description:
Merchants & Marauders lets you live the life of an influential merchant or a dreaded pirate in the Caribbean during the Golden Age of Piracy. Seek your fortune through trade, rumor hunting, missions, and of course, plundering. Modify your ship, buy impressive vessels, load deadly special ammunition, and hire specialist crew members. Will your captain gain eternal glory and immense wealth - or find his wet grave under the stormy surface of the Caribbean Sea?

In Merchants and Marauders, players take on the role of a captain of a small vessel in the Caribbean. The goal is to be the first to achieve 10 "glory" points through performing daring deeds (through the completion of missions or rumors), crushing your enemies (through defeating opponents and NPCs in combat), amassing gold, performing an epic plunder or pulling off the trade of a lifetime, and buying a grand ship. While some points earned from performing various tasks are permanent, players earn points for amassing gold, which can be stolen or lost (or at least diminished) if their captain is killed. Points due to gold are hidden so there's some uncertainty about when the game will end.

A big component of the game is whether (or when) to turn "pirate" or remain as a trader or neutral party. Both careers are fraught with danger: pirates are hunted by NPCs (and other players) for their bounty and blocked to certain ports while traders are hunted by non-player pirates as well as their opponents and generally have to sacrifice combat capability for cargo capacity. Although players can kill each other, there is no player elimination as players may draw a new captain (with a penalty) so it's possible to come back from defeat.

boardgame.name: Take It to the Limit!
boardgame.description:
Take it to the Limit is an advanced version of Take it Easy!. Compared to the original game the boards are bigger in terms of the number of hexagonal spaces. There are 64 tiles in each set, with four different colors running in each direction. These tiles are subdivided evenly into ‘moon’ tiles and ‘sun’ tiles. There are also a number of Gold and Silver bonus tiles. If you complete scoring rows in all three directions through these tiles, then you can also add the bonus values to your total!

The individual playing boards are double-sided, so you can choose to play on the challenging ‘Nexus’ board (45 minutes), or on the stylish Orchid board for a quicker and distinctly different game (25 minutes).

When playing on the Nexus board, all 64 tiles are used. You can enhance your score by skillful use of the Gold and Silver bonus tiles and by cunningly interlacing ‘sunrays’ and ‘moonbeams’ with your other scoring rows. If it all seems to be going desperately wrong, you can dispose of unwanted tiles by placing them in your ‘Scrap Yard’. But beware - an ‘untidy’ scrapyard can cost you penalty points!

When playing on the Orchid board, choose either the ‘sun’ or ‘moon’ tiles. The special orchid symbols allow you to set aside unwanted tiles, with an option to increase your score by relocating them at the end of the game.

boardgame.name: Schmunzel-monster
boardgame.description:
In a colorful fantasy setting players try to escape from the Schmunzelmonster (a dragon-like monster). Each player has 4 Schlammhüpfers ('mud hoppers', the pawns), who try to escape from getting eaten by the Schmunzelmonster by throwing 2 dice. The first die has symbols on it to determine if the Schlammhüpfers will move or the Schmunzelmonster. The second die determines how far it will be moved. Once a direction is chosen, it can only be changed at the middle of the board.

The player with the last Schlammhüpfer remaining wins the game. Schmunzelmonster is a beautiful and colorful game for ages 6 and up.

boardgame.name: Trinity
boardgame.description:
Trinity is a New Zealand designed and published abstract strategy game for 2 players. The game is played on a 4 by 4 square grid, which is marked a-d on the horizontal axis and 1-4 on the vertical axis for record keeping.

There are three types of pieces, which are identical for black and white. First are the ORBS, which are circular pieces with red, yellow, green or blue in the center. The second type of pieces are ARCS, which have a stripe of color matching those of the orbs. The arcs are 120 degrees in extension, so three arcs fit around an orb. HALOS are the third piece type, and are either white or black. They are rings which fit outside the orbs and arcs. There are four orbs, four arcs and six halos of each color, made of plastic.

The orbs are set up on the 1 and 4 rows with the matching color arcs with those orbs. Play consists of each player moving one orb one square horizontally, vertically or diagonally. The matching color of arc MUST be then moved. Arcs can move to any other legal square on the board.

The easiest way to win is to trap an opposing orb with three arcs of any color around it (an Arc-win). If you can box in your opponents orbs so that he has no valid moves, then you have gained an Orb-win. Finally, if you can move your four pieces inside four halos of your own color you have completed a halo win. A draw is an option through player agreement or stalemate from repeated moves.

A halo is "earned" by moving three of your arcs so that they form a complete ring, with no orbs inside it. The arcs then attack the opposing pieces of the same strip color as the arcs.

The game rules come in a 16-page A6 sized rule book. There is also a CD for Windows PCs to practice strategies.

From the underside: "You are stranded in a house as a result of a storm and one of the people present is COUNT DRACULA. The object of the game is for the players to discover the identity of Dracula. Players are gathered in one part of the house and their fate and actions are decided by the spinner. The mood in the house is set by the cassette tape, with the sound of eerie music, doors slamming, wind howling, thunder crashing, along with the VOICE OF DOOM, and the TOLL OF BELLS! You and your friends are guaranteed an evening of laughter, fun and scares. No Game ever plays the same. The more often the game is played the more fun everyone will have as they become skilled in the art of detecting and avoiding Dracula."

The players are travellers which are stuck in a small tavern in the woods during a storm. One of them is Count Dracula, the evil vampire. The players try to discover Dracula's identity.
All players gather around the "wheel of fortune" and explore the playing area from here. They do this trying to flee from the count and his vampire henchmen. If a player is caught, he too turns into a vampire.

boardgame.name: Casey Jones Game Box
boardgame.description: The Casey Jones Game Box contains three games: Blow the Whistle, Capital Run, and Freight Train. All games are played with a single die, and (at most) 20 train cars. Blow the Whistle is a simple race game for two players, playable by children as young as three-years-old. Players roll and move, with the requirement that they make horn sounds at certain points in the game. The first player to reach the finish line wins. Capital Run is a game for older children, with up to four players. This game also has a roll-and-move mechanic, and players must successfully name state capitals in order to earn a turn, with the object to cross the country on a preset path. Freight train is light but nontrivial game for two players, requiring players to assemble a set of different types of trains. These trains (coal tender, box car, flat car, cattle car) begin the game on preset spaces, and players must roll around the board and assemble their set. There are several opportunities for decisions.

boardgame.name: Jr. Quarterback Football Game
Jr. Quarterback Football Game
boardgame.description:
from the Box for the Tee Pee Toys version: All the Thrills of a Big Game: Running Plays, Passing Plays, Kick-Offs, Punts, Field Goals, Punt Returns.You are the Quarterback! Choose your own Plays! Follow the rules of football. Players each roll dice, the numbers on the dice refer to sequence tables which determine the results of the play (one player rolls for offense, and the other rolls for defense). Before rolling the offensive player must state whether he is going to run, kick, or pass. The game consists of "Four Quarters" four sets of (20) plays each quarter. The player with the highest score at the end wins.

Alternate version: Jr. Quarterback came with short game board, markers for downs and quarter of play, a cardboard football and a deck of 20 cards with plays. One quarter of play was one complete pass through the 20 plays card deck. Thus, the deck would be gone through twice per half and 4 times to complete one game. The offensive player would select a play. The card would be turned over to reveal the results. Following the rules of football i.e., 4 downs to gain 10 yards, 4 quarters of play, etc.) the ball would move up and down the field based on the play called and the associated gain or loss in yardage on the card associated with the play called. The plays that could be called were "left end", "left tackle", "left guard", "right end", "right tackle", "right guard", "short pass" and "long pass" as well as "punt", "kickoff" and "field goal". Each of the running plays had gains and losses as well as one fumble and a no gain. "Long pass" had four interceptions including one that was returned for a touchdown. "Long pass" also offered a touchdown. Short pass had a higher completion rate than long pass and only two interceptions. Jr. Quarterback is a fun game for two young players and can even be played by one. In my opinion ages elementary or for the adult who likes old school board games from a simpler time. Great game for teaching a young child the basics.

boardgame.name: A passo d'oca
La course des canards
Gänsemarsch
Goose March
boardgame.description:
A children's game, consisting of 32 cards with geese on both sides and a dice. The 32 cards are arranged in a spiral and all players start from the first card. After throwing the dice the player moves accordingly forward on the spiral. If he lands on a card, he has to turn it around and follow its instructions.
The card symbols are sometimes advantageous (e.g. take another turn), sometimes disadvantageous (e.g. sit out one turn). The players can also move other pawns of other players to move them on disadvantageous cards. Therefore it is essential to remember what text is on the backside of the cards.
If two geese meet, one has to follow the orders from the backside of the card, the other must go back to the card where the first goose came from. The player wins, whose goose first passes the last card of the spiral.

boardgame.name: Il Golpe
boardgame.description:
Wargame for two players, originally included with issues no. 728, 729 (the regular 6-sided die) and 730 of Italian magazine "Panorama", in spring 1980.

From the rules' sheet:

"Il Golpe, a bespoke creation for "Panorama", is a war game based on a hypothetical military coup in Italy.
The game's flow simulates the typical putsch's mechanics: mutiny of military units, assaults against TV broadcasting stations, airports, nuclear plants and naval bases, riots in the streets.
The game represents a single day of war, consisting in 8 phases of 3 hours each. At the beginning of the game the "rebel" player secretly compiles a list with the opponent's units that will mutiny, then the "government" player places his army and only after this stage is the list revealed. At the end of the game the total value of the "strategic goals" achieved by the "rebel" player is calculated, and if his total score is higher than the "government" player's one (the sum of the objectives still under his control) the coup d'etat is successful."

Contents:
Map of Italy (84 x 39,5 cm) with reference charts embedded;
107 cardboards chits;
1 dice;

boardgame.name: Zzzymble
boardgame.description:
Zzzymble is a card game inspired by Sudoku and is a fast paced card game that is fun for all ages.

The box contains cards with five suits, containing the numbers 1-9, plus various special cards that affect gameplay. Players are trying to play their cards into a 5x5 grid. Cards may not be played adjacently (orthogonally or diagonally) to another card that match either number or color. When the grid is full, players sum card values remaining in their hands. Over a number of rounds (playing to 100 points), the winner is the player with the fewest points.

A planned forthcoming expansion is called "It's as Zzzymble as Zzzat."

boardgame.name: Cribbage: The Board Game
Roughrider Cribbage
boardgame.description: “Cribbage - The Board Game” is a simple, fast game for anyone who enjoys playing the traditional cribbage card game. Unlike the traditional card game, the board game can only be played with two teams and therefore cannot be played by three players. Fortunately (and uniquely) this cribbage game can be played very well with six players forming two teams of three. Each team alternates play by placing a card on the board from their dealt hand. The board is a five by five grid with a face down card in the center revealed only after all cards are played. At the end of each round one team will score the cribbage “hands” that form the “rows” while the other team scores the cribbage “hands” that form the “columns”. Every card placed will become a card in one of your cribbage “hands” on the board but will also be a card in one of your opponents “hands”. The trick therefore is to strategically place cards in such a way to help yourself but hinder your opponent. The board also has card values printed on some spots for instant scoring. Placing a queen on a spot on the board with a queen printed on it will score an instant two points - just as matching a pair during regular play would in a traditional cribbage game. Placing a five on the same queen spot would similarly score an instant two points for the fifteen. Final scoring is done after all spaces are filled using the same procedure one uses for a traditional cribbage hand. First team to 121 wins. If you like to play cribbage, especially with a group, this is a fun twist on one of the world’s oldest card games.
